awd_titl_txt: SG: The demographic and life-history consequences of re-colonizing secondary habitats
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical forests are one of the most diverse and complex ecosystems on earth.  They are also one of the most productive systems for conversion to agriculture, leading to large scale deforestation and local extinction of wildlife that once lived in those forests. While tropical deforestation for agricultural uses is still common, social and economic forces are shifting attention to manufacturing jobs in cities and resulting in abandonment of agricultural areas. As a result, forests are starting to re-grow and expand through a process called succession. The re-growing forests, called "secondary" forests, are different from the original forests; they have smaller trees and less canopy cover.  Eventually, the wildlife that were lost with deforestation will re-colonize these secondary forests.  This project will examine how wildlife find and live in secondary forests. The investigators will focus on small lizards and test ideas about which individuals are able to thrive in the forests and why they are able to do so. Results will be important for management of both forests and wildlife, as both change under human influences.   

Range expansion theory provides a testable framework to study the ecological, genetics and evolutionary mechanisms driving the recolonization of secondary habitats by wildlife species.  This theory makes four fundamental predictions: A recolonizing population will (1) be composed highly dispersive individuals, (2) experience higher population growth rates, (3) experience escape and release from natural enemies, and (4) have lower genetic diversity when compared to the source population. The study follows an interdisciplinary approach that combines an observational study, a field experiment, demographic modeling and genomic analyses to test these predictions in Anolis gundlachi, a shaded-forest-specialist lizard re-colonizing secondary forests following large-scale forest recovery in Puerto Rico. We understand the general patterns of re-colonization showing that secondary forests of > 20 years can hold up to 92% of old-growth forest species. This study will advance the field through a robust multi-scale evaluation of the processes and mechanisms driving the evolution of life-history traits during secondary forest re-colonization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tropical forests are one of the most diverse and complex ecosystems on earth. These forests are also one of the most productive systems for agricultural use leading to the deforestation of large areas for food production. This deforestation eventually results in the local extinction of wildlife inhabiting these sites. While tropical forest disturbance for agricultural uses is prevalent in the tropics, socioeconomic changes are shifting economic activities from agriculture to manufacturing. This shift results in migration of humans from rural areas to cities and the abandonment of agricultural sites. These abandoned sites slowly get reforested through a process called succession. These new forests are often called secondary forests because their structure is different from the forests that inhabited the place before disturbance. These forests often have smaller trees and less canopy cover. After some time, these secondary forests develop the minimum requirements for wildlife species that went locally extinct to recolonize. Secondary forests will be more prevalent in the future and this study provides insights into the ecological and evolutionary processes driving this recolonization.

 

Range expansion theory provides a testable framework to study the ecological and evolutionary mechanisms driving the recolonization of secondary habitats by wildlife species. This theory makes four fundamental predictions: A small recolonizing population (1) will have physical traits such as larger body sizes or longer limbs which are traits related to movement ability, (2) experience lower densities that can lead to higher population growth rates, (3) experience escape and release from parasitism, and (4) have lower genetic diversity when compared to the source population. The study follows an interdisciplinary approach that combines an observational study, a field experiment, and genomic analyses to test these predictions in the recolonization of the lizard Anolis gundlachi in Puerto Rico. This process of recolonization may change through time. Therefore we studied hese populations 30 years after recolonization. We compared lizard traits among forest of different ages. Young forests had < 30 years, mid forests 30-50, and old forests > 70 years. The processes that governs recolonization may be different at the beginning stages of recolonization. To evaluate the process at this temporal scale we conducted a field experiment were we planted small trees at two distances from the forest and compared the traits of the lizards that ventured to use these small trees to those living in the old-growth population. 

 

Overall, our study found support for three of the four predictions. We found that lizards in the young forests were larger than those living in old forest but the pattern was reversed in the experiment that represented the initial recolonization process---individuals using trees far from the forest were smaller. Still, these patterns varied by geographic location. Lizard densities were smaller in the young forests which suggests potential for less competition and higher population growth rates. We also found lower parasitism rates by malarial parasites in the young forests which supports the hypothesis of escape and release from natural enemies. Nevertheless, we found no evidence of differences in genetic diversity. All in all, our results show that the individuals that recolonize secondary forests are not necessarily a random subset of the individuals in the source population. The traits they bring plus the new conditions of these recovering forests create a unique set of adaptive pressures that determine the traits that persist in the population. Given that recovering forests are a key component of future landscapes this information is valuable to better understand and manage recovering populations.

This study provided an opportunity to train eight undergraduate students, and a graduate student (seven from underrepresented minorities in stem) in experimental design, field techniques, disease diagnostics, and data analysis.


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Miguel A Acevedo

Image
  • This is our study species, Anolis gundlachi, a shade specialist lizard that lives in closed canopy forest and is recently recolonizing recovering forests in Puerto Rico
    Miguel Acevedo
    Miguel A Acevedo
    Anolis gundlachi
